title: How to Grow Cucumbers Indoors

steps.headline: Choose hybrid cucumber seeds that don’t require pollination.
steps.description: Be sure to buy a dwarf variety in order to conserve space.

steps.headline: Select a very large pot.
steps.description: Cucumbers even dwarf varieties, need lots of room to grow. You can also grow cucumbers in hanging pots.

steps.headline: Place some small stones, clay shards or gravel in the bottom of the pot to aid drainage and to keep the roots of the plant from getting soggy.
steps.description: You can also place a small pot (with drainage holes) upside down in the middle of the large pot if you don't have rocks or gravel.

steps.headline: Fill your planting pot with a mixture of potting soil and compost—50% soil and 50% compost.
steps.description: You can use dirt from your garden, but then you will run the risk of bringing unwanted pests indoors.

steps.headline: Plant 4 to 5 seeds about 1/2” (12 mm) deep.
steps.description: Space the seeds 1/2" apart or more, if possible. Planting them too close together will hinder growth.

steps.headline: Water the soil thoroughly so that it is saturated, but not soupy.
steps.description: Water several times until the water drains from the bottom of the pot.

steps.headline: Position your cucumber planter in a sunny window.
steps.description: For optimal growth, the plant should receive at least 6 hours of sunlight a day.

steps.headline: Allow the seedlings to grow to a height of 2 to 3” (50 to 75 mm).
steps.description: Don't thin them before they reach this minimum height.

steps.headline: Identify 2 plants that look the strongest and gently pull the other plants out of the soil.
steps.description: Be careful not to disturb the soil around the 2 plants you want to keep.

steps.headline: Let the remaining 2 plants grow to a height of about 10” (254 mm).
steps.description: Rotate the planter every few days if it looks like the plants are not receiving the same amount of sunlight.

steps.headline: Choose the strongest, healthiest of the two plants to keep and eliminate the other one by snipping it off at the base.
steps.description: This will leave you with 1 strong and healthy cucumber plant that will produce well and won’t be crowded.

steps.headline: Insert a stick or small trellis near the plant so that you can train the vine to climb.
steps.description: Don't wait too long to do this; the plant will start climbing as much as 1" every day, depending on the amount of sunlight it is receiving.

steps.headline: Water your plant frequently so that the soil stays moist.
steps.description: Make sure the water thoroughly drains out from the bottom of the planter, so you will know that the roots are getting wet.
